bioghist.p: Sinclair Oil Corporation was founded by Harry F. Sinclair in 1916. In 1930, Sinclair began using the apatosaurus (brontosaurus) in its advertising, sales promotions, and product labels. In 1933 at the Chicago Worlds Fair Sinclair sponsored a dinosaur exhibit which included a two-ton animated model of a apatosaurus. In 1964 at the New York City Worlds Fair, Sinclair displayed an exhibit featuring nine life-sized dinosaurs highlighting its unique association with the age of the dinosaur--an age representative of the beginning of the formation of crude oil.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of materials from the Sinclair Oil Company, related to its use of dinosaurs in company marketing and also its connection with the Teapot Dome Oil scandal. Materials in the collection include: photographs from the Chicago Century of Progress Exhibition, 1933; Dinoland at the New York World's Fair, 1964-1965; photographs from the American Museum of Natural History/Sinclair Dinosaur Expedition in 1934; and booklets, brochures, stamps, clippings, and ephemera from the Sinclair dinosaur advertising campaign. The collection also includes a series of letters to Bruce Quayle from various natural history museums in response to his queries about dinosaur exhibits (1964-1965). Documents related to the Teapot Dome case include letters to stockholders from Robert W. Stewart, John D. Rockefeller, and Winthrop W. Aldrich and photocopies of newspaper articles about the case.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
